questions.explanation:
Dehydration

Overhydration (Volume gained in ECF)

A. ISOTONIC DEHYDRATION

  • Water & Na+ lost in equal proportions

B. HYPERTONIC DEHYDRATION

Phases

Characteristics
0 (Depolarization) Opening of fast Na channels.
1 (Initial repolarization) Closure of fast Na channels & K+ efflux through open K+ channels.

questions.text: A neuroscientist in his research studies the brains of humans during different periods and in certain psychiatric conditions. He observes that a child's brain can learn and recover from injury faster than an adult brain. Moreover, the neuronal circuits of humans keep evolving with changes in learning, behavior, memory, and psychiatric disorders. These circuits are maintained by way of neuronal connections that are both chemical and electrical. Which of the following characteristic of a synapse likely explains these modifications in the brain and is not an advantage of an electrical impulse over a chemical impulse?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Plasticity is the ability of the brain to change and adapt to new information . It is the capacity to modify neurocircuits and change subsequent thoughts, feelings, and behavior .
  • ↳ Synaptic plasticity is a change that occurs at synapses and controls how effectively two neurons communicate with each other . It specifically Referenceers to the activity-dependent modification of the strength or efficacy of synaptic transmission at pre-existing synapses.
  • ↳ They play a central role in the capacity of the brain to incorporate transient experiences into persistent memory traces .
  • ↳ It may either decrease the efficacy of the synapse, called depression, or increase the efficacy, called potentiation. Synaptic plasticity can be either long-term or short-term.
  • ↳ The transmission of information in the central nervous system is mainly through nerve action potentials called nerve impulses. There are two major synapses: the chemical synapse and the electrical synapse .
  • ↳ In chemical synapses, the neuron secretes a chemical substance called a neurotransmitter at its nerve ending. This transmitter acts on receptor proteins of the next neuron to excite the neuron and inhibit or modify its sensitivity .
  • ↳ Electrical synapses are distinguished by open fluid channels that conduct electricity directly from one cell to the next. Most of these synapses consist of small protein tubular structures called gap junctions that allow the movement of ions freely from the interior of one cell to the interior of the next.
  • ↳ Option A: Narrow time domain
  • ↳ The events at the electrical synapses occur in a narrow timeframe. The conduction is faster because the gap junctions enable immediate ion passage . It is a cell association between two nerve cells where ions are used to transmit nerve impulses rapidly. They are smaller, and the information is transmitted at a high rate.
  • ↳ The events at the electrical synapses occur in a narrow timeframe. The conduction is faster because the gap junctions enable immediate ion passage .
  • ↳ It is a cell association between two nerve cells where ions are used to transmit nerve impulses rapidly.
  • ↳ They are smaller, and the information is transmitted at a high rate.
  • ↳ Option B: Bidirectionality
  • ↳ Chemical synapses have a characteristic that makes them quite desirable for transmitting most nervous system signals. The transmission of signals is always in one direction, from the presynaptic neuron to the postsynaptic neuron . In contrast, conduction through electrical synapses often transmits signals in either or both direction s.
  • ↳ Chemical synapses have a characteristic that makes them quite desirable for transmitting most nervous system signals.
  • ↳ The transmission of signals is always in one direction, from the presynaptic neuron to the postsynaptic neuron .
  • ↳ In contrast, conduction through electrical synapses often transmits signals in either or both direction s.
  • ↳ Option D: No latency
  • ↳ Latency is the delay in the transmission of nerve impulses along a synapse. In electrical synapses, there is no latency or synaptic delay. The conduction is faster. The gap junctions enable immediate ion passage compared to chemical synapses, where information is transmitted slowly.
  • ↳ Latency is the delay in the transmission of nerve impulses along a synapse.
  • ↳ In electrical synapses, there is no latency or synaptic delay. The conduction is faster. The gap junctions enable immediate ion passage compared to chemical synapses, where information is transmitted slowly.

questions.text: Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from mechanoreceptors?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Gate Control Theory
  • ➤ Gate Control Theory
  • ➤ Psychologist Ronald Melzack and the anatomist Patrick Wall proposed the gate control theory for pain in 1965 to explain the pain suppression. According to them, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by a gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed. Significance of Gate Control: Gating of pain at the spinal level is similar to presynaptic inhibition. It forms the basis for relief of pain through rubbing, massage techniques, application of ice packs, acupuncture, and electrical analgesia. All these techniques relieve pain by stimulating the release of endogenous pain relievers (opioid peptides), which close the gate and block the pain signals. Stimulation of Aβ fibers from peripheral tactile receptors can decrease transmission of pain signals by lateral inhibition- This is known as the Gate control mechanism of pain.
  • ➤ Psychologist Ronald Melzack and the anatomist Patrick Wall proposed the gate control theory for pain in 1965 to explain the pain suppression. According to them, the pain stimuli transmitted by afferent pain fibers are blocked by a gate mechanism located at the posterior gray horn of spinal cord. If the gate is opened, pain is felt. If the gate is closed, pain is suppressed.
  • ➤ Significance of Gate Control: Gating of pain at the spinal level is similar to presynaptic inhibition. It forms the basis for relief of pain through rubbing, massage techniques, application of ice packs, acupuncture, and electrical analgesia. All these techniques relieve pain by stimulating the release of endogenous pain relievers (opioid peptides), which close the gate and block the pain signals.
  • ➤ Significance of Gate Control:
  • ➤ Stimulation of Aβ fibers from peripheral tactile receptors can decrease transmission of pain signals by lateral inhibition- This is known as the Gate control mechanism of pain.
  • ➤ lateral inhibition-
  • ➤ This process is mediated by inhibitory interneurons in the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Aα neurons project to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract. Aδ fibers and type C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.
  • ➤ This process is mediated by inhibitory interneurons in the dorsal column of the spinal cord.
  • ➤ Aα neurons project to skeletal muscles, causing them to contract.
  • ➤ Aδ fibers and type C fibers conduct pain signals to the dorsal column of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presented to the clinic complaining of fever, lethargy and facial swelling. Complete blood count shows pancytopenia, and renal function tests show creatinine 5mg/dl. The anti-double-stranded antibody is ordered, which comes out positive. A diagnosis of lupus nephritis is made. Which of the following hypersensitivity reactions with corresponding diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura is an example of Hypersensitivity type 1

options.label: B
options.text: Reactive Arthritis Hypersensitivity is an example of Hypersensitivity type 3

options.label: C
options.text: Rheumatoid Arthritis is an example of Hypersensitivity type 2

options.label: D
options.text: Anaphylaxis is an example of Hypersensitivity type 4

questions.correct_answer: B. Reactive Arthritis Hypersensitivity is an example of Hypersensitivity type 3
questions.explanation:
Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type 2 Hypersensitivity

  • Associated with the Production of IgG, IgM which binds to an antigen on the target cell or tissue.
  • Causing phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes.
  • ITP is a type 2 HSR.

Type 1 Hypersensitivity

  • Associated with the Production of IgE antibody leading to the immediate release of vasoactive amines and other mediators from mast cells; later recruitment of inflammatory cells. Examples: Anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma

Type 3 Hypersensitivity

  • Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes →complement activation → recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors →release of enzymes and other toxic molecules Examples: SLE, serum sickness, Arthus reaction, Reactive Arthritis

Type 4 Hypersensitivity

  • Associated with Activated T lymphocytes → (1) release of cytokines, Inflammation, and macrophage activation; (2) T cell-mediated cytotoxicity Examples: Type 1 DM, Contact dermatitis, Rheumatoid Arthritis

                             Mechanism of action

Macrolides 

Inhibit the translocation

Chloramphenicol

 

Binding to the 23S fraction of the 50S ribosome at A site and inhibit peptide bond formation by blocking peptidyltranferase.

Binding to the 23S fraction of the 30S ribosome at A site prevents addition of amino acids to the growing peptide.

Binding to the 23S fraction of the 30S ribosome at P site and interferes with:

questions.text: Subject bias is the tendency of the subject or participant in a study to react, either consciously or unconsciously which impacts the results. All of the following are Subject biases except?
questions.explanation:
BIAS DEFINITION
Apprehension bias Systemic alterations in the parameter of interest due to apprehension
Hawthorne effect Study subjects may alter their behavior upon observation
Berksonian bias Bias due to differences in admission rates of hospital cases and controls
Interviewer bias Due to the interviewer's differential time allotment to cases and controls
Lead time bias The bias of over-estimation of survival time due to backward shift of starting point, as by screening procedures
Recall bias Due to faulty recall of information by study subjects
Neyman bias Bias due to missing of fatal cases, silent cases, and cases of short duration
Selection bias Groups compared are differentially susceptible to the outcome of interest

A 62-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of fatigue that increases with work. The patient says she gets tired quite early without completing her tasks and takes long breaks to complete them. She has a history of breathing and eating difficulty. There is no accident or fall history. She is a non-smoker with no drug abuse history. Her blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, and her pulse is 80 beats/min. Physical examination reveals that there is a dropping in eyelids and blurry vision. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. A test is performed on the patient's eye, as given in the image below. questions.explanation:
Disease Features/tests
Multiple system atrophy MRI showing hot cross buns sign and Putamen atrophy
Trigeminal neuralgia unilateral, intermittent, shock-like pain. Triggers include chewing, brushing or any light touch
Hypokalemic periodic paralysis CMAP compound muscle action potential shows a low amplitude and no exercise improvement.
Myasthenia Gravis

Nerve conduction study( decremental response)

Ice pack test (for ptosis)

Diagnostic Test/Workup

Description and Purpose

Anti ACh-R Antibody

- Screening test positive in 85% cases.

Anti M.U.S.K Antibody

- Targets muscle-specific kinase.

Anti LRP4 Antibody

- Targets Low Density Lipoprotein Receptor-Related Protein 4.

S.F.EMG - Single Fibre Electromyography

- Confirms diagnosis through jitter and blocking findings.

- Measures amplitude of contraction; decreased in affected muscles.

- Preferred over other tests.
 
 

RNS - Repetitive Nerve Stimulation Test

- Detects decremental response in muscle performance.

Anticholinesterase Test / Tensilon Test

- Edrophonium injected; short-acting.

- Gradual dosage to avoid cholinergic crisis.

- Positive response indicated by improved ptosis or muscle strength.
 
 

Ice Pack Test

- Similar to Tensilon Test; reduces acetylcholinesterase activity.

- Similar sensitivity to Tensilon Test.
 

CT/MRI Head

- Rules out central causes affecting nerves.

CT Chest

- Detects mass effects of thymoma.

- Thymectomy impact on steroid requirements and side effects.
 

Antibody Testing for Autoimmune Diseases

- Identifies coexisting autoimmune conditions.

PFT - Pulmonary Function Test

- Assesses lung function and reserve.

- Important before surgery, especially in obese patients.

- Considers steroid impact on other conditions.

questions.explanation:
Extrapyramidal Effects

 

 Clinical features

 

 Pharmacotherapy

 

Acute dystonia

Sudden sustained contraction of the neck, mouth, tongue, and eye muscles presenting as:

  • Oculogyric crisis, ocular muscles spasm, and opisthotonos
  • Torticollis
  • Laryngospasm
  • Grimacing

Earliest to develop. Occurs within days of drug usage.

Anticholinergic drugs:

  • Benztropine
  • Diphenhydramine

Acute akathisia
  • Constant purposeless involuntary movement from one place to another.
  • Most common EPS.
  • Occurs within days to weeks
  • Propranolol
  • Lorazepam
  • Benztropine

Tardive dyskinesia

Gradual onset after prolonged therapy (>6 months). Usually presents after years of treatment.

Dyskinesia of the mouth, face trunk, and extremities causing:

  • chewing and sucking movements
  • grimacing
  • choreoathetosis movements
  • Deutetrabenazine
  • Valbenazine

Malignant neuroleptic syndrome

Most serious side effect. Presents as:

  • Hyperthermia
  • Severe muscular rigidity and dystonia
  • Akinesia
  • Mutism
  • Fluctuating level of consciousness
  • Agitation
  • Tachycardia
  • High blood pressure

Laboratory findings include:

  • Increased WBC count
  • Increased level of CPK
  • Increased level of liver enzymes
  • Increased levels of plasma myoglobin and myoglobinuria
  • Occasionally renal failure
  • Immediately stop>
  • Medically cool the patient
  • Monitor vital signs
  • Dantrolene (skeletal muscle relaxant)
  • Bromocriptine or Amantadine

Drug-induced parkinsonism

Gradual onset tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Occurs within weeks to months
  • Benztropine
  • Amantadine

A 34-year-old man presents to the fertility clinic for evaluation of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to have children for two years. His wife was recently evaluated and found to be normal and healthy. The patient denies any pain in his testicular region. However, he reports occasional feelings of heaviness in his scrotum. On physical exam, his scrotum looks distended. At rest, a "bag of worm"-like finding is visible and palpable in the testicle. What is the grade of the given condition?
questions.explanation:
Varicocele Grading
Grade 1

 

 Palpable during Valsalva manoeuvre, but not otherwise

 
Grade 2

 

 Palpable at rest but not visible

 
Grade 3

 

 Visible and palpable at rest

 

Topic Varicocele
Definition Varicocele is a condition characterized by the enlargement and dilation of the veins within the scrotum, specifically the pampiniform plexus of veins. It is similar to varicose veins that occur in the legs.
Causes The exact cause of varicocele is not always clear, but it is primarily due to the failure of valves within the spermatic veins. These valves normally prevent backflow of blood, but when they malfunction, blood pools and causes the veins to enlarge. Varicoceles are more common on the left side due to the anatomy of the left testicular vein.
Prevalence Varicoceles are relatively common, affecting approximately 15% of adult males and up to 35% of males with fertility problems. They are most commonly diagnosed during adolescence and early adulthood.
Clinical Features - A soft, bag of worms-like feeling of the scrotum when palpated.
  - Dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, particularly after prolonged standing or physical activity.
  - Often asymptomatic and may be incidentally discovered during routine physical examinations or fertility evaluations.
Diagnosis Diagnosis is based on a combination of physical examination and imaging tests, such as scrotal ultrasound, to assess the size and location of the varicocele.
Grading Varicoceles can be graded based on their size and palpability:
  - Grade 0: No palpable or visible varicocele.
  - Grade 1: Palpable with Valsalva maneuver, not visible in standing position.
  - Grade 2: Palpable and visible in standing position.
  - Grade 3: Large and easily visible without Valsalva maneuver.
Management Treatment may be considered for symptomatic varicoceles or those affecting fertility. Conservative measures include scrotal support and pain management. Surgical procedures, such as varicocelectomy or embolization, may be performed to correct the varicocele and improve fertility in select cases.
Complications Varicoceles are generally benign, but they can be associated with male infertility due to increased scrotal temperature, altered testicular blood flow, and potential negative effects on sperm quality. In some cases, they may cause testicular atrophy (shrinkage) and chronic testicular pain (rare).

questions.text: A 46-year-old male mechanical engineer, who was brought by his wife reported that he was fasted for 25 days prior to presentation and that he only ingested water for that period under the influence of a Swamiji. He broke his fast today by eating breakfast after which he became extremely confused and restless. All of the following are true about the condition the patient is suffering from except:

options.label: B
options.text: Associated with increased risk of arrhythmia

options.label: C
options.text: Occur with rapid & excessive feeding of patients with severe underlying malnutrition

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ Refeeding is the process of reintroducing food after a prolonged period of malnourishment or starvation. Refeeding syndrome is a serious and potentially lethal condition that can occur during rapid refeeding. It is caused by sudden shifts in the electrolytes which leads to electrolyte imbalances like hypomagnesemia hypophosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hypokalemia. It is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmia.

Pathophysiology

→ With refeeding, shift in metabolism from fat to carbohydrate substrate

→ Increased insulin release → Cellular uptake of electrolytes particularly:

− Phosphate → Hypophosphatemia

− Magnesium → Hypomagnesemia

− Potassium→ Hypokalemia

− Calcium→ Hypocalcemia

→ Increased risk of arrhythmia, confusion, respiratory failure, liver dysfunction, seizure, coma & death due to dyselectrolytemia

→ Treatment- matching intakes with requirements and avoiding overfeeding

→ Hypophosphatemia and hypomagnesemia require treatment

questions.text: A female patient is scheduled for cholecystectomy. The surgeon uses an instrument to hold skin and subcutaneous tissue for retraction. What is the name of this instrument?

True about the suture material shown in the image: A. Undergoes phagocytosis and enzymatic degradation B. Synthetic absorbable suture C. Has the highestaffinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus D. Absorbed in 180 days
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective:
  • ➤ Surgical suture materials are used in the closure of most wounds either traumatic or surgical. The ideal suture should allow the healing tissue to recover sufficiently to keep the wound closed together once the sutures are removed or absorbed. These sutures may be either absorbable or non-absorbable based on the material it is made of. Polydioxanone is a synthetic absorbable suture. It has the lowest affinity for adherence to E.coli and S. Aureus. Surgically used suture material polydioxanone undergoes hydrolysis and complete absorption. It is resistant to enzymatic degradation and phagocytosis.

Suture Types Raw material Tensile strength retention in vivo Absorption rate Tissue reaction Contraindications Frequent uses
Polydioxanone (PDS)

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

 Polyester polymer

Approximately 70% remains at 2 weeks

Approximately 50% remains at 4 weeks

Approximately 14% remains at 8 weeks

Hydrolysis minimal at 90 days

Complete absorption at 180 days

 Mild Not for use in association with heart valves or synthetic grafts or in situations where prolonged tissue approximation under stress is required Used as alternative for other absorbable sutures in a particular place where slightly longer wound support is required

questions.text: What is the most beneficial screening test for a 21-year-old female who has been sexually active for the past three years, has no familial history of cancer or cardiac diseases?

A 29-year-old G2P1L1 at 24 weeks presents for a routine check-up . Patient has no major complains except for occassional palpitations. Her blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg . There is no pedal edema or breathlessness, and her ECG is normal. All of the following are physiological changes in pregnancy causing such presentation, except?
questions.correct_answer: D. Increase in peripheral vascular resistance
questions.explanation:
Physiological changes of the cardiovascular system in pregnancy

Normal pregnancy is characterised by

  • Increased plasma volume (preload)
  • Increased Cardiac Output
  • Increased heart rate
  • Decreased Peripheral vascular resistance.
  • These changes result in a physiologic decrease in mean blood pressure during the second trimester.

options.label: B

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of lesions on his elbow and shaft of the penis. On examination, pinhead-shaped (discrete but grouped papules) lesions over the right elbow are noted as shown below: Which of the following is the most likely disorder:
questions.explanation:
Lichen Nitidus Lichen Planus Phrynoderma Scabies
  • Minute, pinpoint to pinhead-sized, and have a flat or dome-shaped, shiny surface.
  • Forearms, penis, abdomen, chest, and buttocks.
  • Firm, shiny, polygonal, 1-3 mm diameter papules (isolated or grouped, in a linear or annular distribution) with a red to violet color with a lattice of thin white lines - Wickham's striae.
  • Volar aspect of wrist, ankle, lumbar region.
  • Annular lesions- penis
  • Keratotic follicular papules involve the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral upper arms and can spread to the extensor extremities, shoulders, posterior neck, back, buttocks, and abdomen
  • Typical locations of lesions are the finger webs, the flexor surfaces of the wrists, the elbows, the axillae, the buttocks and genitalia, and the breasts of women.
  • The typical lesions of scabies are burrows.
  • Inflammatory pruritic papules or nodules.
